explanations: Noun/Verb じしょ-form + ことが できません was explained in lesson 18 as a form expressing potential
Here we explain potential verbs in another form
For group 1 ます-form verbs, drop ます, change the last syllable from the う-column to the え-column
examples: 1) かきます → かけます
1) かきます → かける
1) To write
1) かいます → かえます
1) かいます → かえる
1) To buy

explanations: From じしょ-form, remove the last る and append られる
examples: 1) たべます → たべられます
1) たべます → たべられる
1) To eat

explanations: From じしょ-form, if くる, remove last する and append こられる
From じしょ-form, if not くる, remove last する and append できる
examples: 1) きます → こられます
1) きます → こられる
1) To come
2) します → できます
2) します → できる
2) To be able to

topic: Sentences in which potential verbs are used
explanations: Potential verbs indicate states, not actions.
Hence, although the object of a transitive verb is indicated by by the particle を, the object of a potential verb is usually indicated by が
A potential verb can be used to state someone's ability to do something, or to indicate that an action is possible in a certain situation
[Note] Particles other than を remain the same
examples: 1) 私[わたし]は 日本語[にほんご]を はなします。
1) I speak Japanese
2) 私[わたし]は 日本語[にほんご]を はなせます。
2) I can speak Japanese
3) 一人[ひとり]で 病院[びょういん]へ 行[い]けますか。
3) Can you get to the hospital by yourself?
4) 田中[たなか]さんに 会[あ]えませんでした。
4) I was unable to see Tanaka
5) ミラさんは 漢字[かんじ]が 読[よ]めます。
5) Mr Miller can read Kanji
6) この 銀行[ぎんこう]で ドルが 換[か]えられます
6) You can exchange dollars at this bank

topic: 見[み]えます and 聞[き]こえます
explanations: みえます and きこえます are not volitional, they denote something(indicated by が) natturally coming into sight, or a sound naturally reaching one's ears, independent of one's will
みえます and きこえます cannot be used to talk about a person deliberately pasying attention to something, in that case, a potential verb is used
examples: 1) 新幹線[しんかんせん]から 富士山[ふじさん]が 見[み]えます。
1) You can see Mt Fuji from the Shinkansen
2) ラジオの 音[おと]が 聞[き]こえます。
2) The sound of a radio can be heard
3) 新宿[しんじゅく]で 今[いま] 黒沢[くろさわ]の 映画[えいが]が 見[み]られます。
3) You can watch a Kurosawa movie at Shinjuku at the moment
4) 電話[でんわ]で 天気[てんき]予報[よほう]が 聞[き]けます。
4) You can listen to the weather forcast on the telephone

explanations: The sense of the verb できます introduced here is to 'come into being', 'be completed', 'be finished', 'be made', etc
examples: 1) 駅[えき]の 前[まえ]に 大[おお]きい スーパーが できました。
1) A big supermarket has been built in front of the station
2) 時計[とけい]の 修理[しゅうり]は いつ できますか。
2) When can this watch be repaired?

explanations: しか is appended to nouns, quantifiers, etc, and is always used with a negative.
A sentence that contains it negates everything except the word to which it was attached
When used with a noun to which a particle is attached, it is appended to the particle unless this is が or を，which is replaces
examples: 1) ローマ字[じ]しか 書[か]けません。
1) I can only write Romanji (But nothing else)
2) ローマ字[じ]だけ かけます。
2) I can only write Romanji

explanations: In addition to introducing a topic, は can also indicate a contrast
examples: 1) ワインは 飲[の]みますが，ビールは 飲[の]みません。
1) I drink wine, but I don't drink beer
2) 昨日[きのう]は 山[やま]が 見[み]えましたが，今日[きょう]は 見[み]えません。
2) The mountains were visible yesterday, but not today

topic: は used to highlight a word with another particle already attached
explanations: When は is used with a noun to which a particle is attached, it is appended to the particle unless this is が or を，which is replaces
examples: 1) 日本[にほん]では 馬[うま]を 見[み]る ことが できます。
1) You can't see any horses in Japan
2) 天気[てんき]の いい 日[ひ]には 海[うみ]が 見[み]えるんです。
2) On a fine day, you can see the sea
3) ここからは 東京[とうきょう]スカイツリーが 見[み]えません。
3) You can't see the Tokyo Sky Tree from here
